    tools.generaltools module¶

    This module contains decorators used in most of the packages of this project.

    The decorators designed in this modules are not specific to the project and are used in most of the other packages.

    get_nb_lines_file(infile)[source]¶

    Open an eventually zipped file and return its number of lines.

    This function opens the file received as argument and open it depending on its extension (For the moment, only classic text files and gzipped files can be opened.)

    Parameters:infile (str) – Complete or relative path to the file you want to open you want to explore.
    Returns:The number of lines in the file.
    Return type:int
    Raises:AssertError – Raised when the types of the arguments are not respected.
    list_elements(path_to_folder, type_=None, extension='', sort='natural', exception=None, verbose=False)[source]¶

    List the items in a given folder with a few filters.

    This function list all the elements in the folder given You can chose to select only one type of object with type_. It is also possible to look only for the objects ending with a specific string given to extension. The output is a list which can be sorted by alphanumerical or natural order with sort VERBOSE makes the function print all the files found in the specified path (by default VERBOSE=False), It is possible to sort the list of files by natural order before it is returned with sort="natural" (activated by default) or alphanumerical order.

    Parameters:
    • path_to_folder (str) – Complete or relative path to the folder you want to explore.
    • type (str|None, optional) – Type of items you want to list, can be "dir", "file" or None (default behavior). When set to None, the function does not care about the type and returns all items.
    • extension (str, optional) – Add a filter to the function to only return the items whose name finish with the string given to extension. By default extension is an empty string.
    • sort (str, optional) – Indicate how the output list is sorted. By default, the output is sorted by natural order ( sort="natural"). It can also be set to :code:`sort=”alphanumeric”.
    • exception (list|tuple|None, optional) – List or tuple of specific items to ignore. By defaultNone
    • verbose (bool, optional) – Makes the function print more information. (False by default)
    Returns:
    Return type:

    list
    Raises:

    AssertError – Raised when the types of the arguments are not respected.

    Examples

    To get the list of the python files in the current directory:
    >>> elements = list_elements(".", extension=".py")
>>> expected_out = [
... os.path.join('.', '__init__.py'), os.path.join('.',
... 'generaldecorators.py'), os.path.join('.', 'generaltools.py')]
>>> elements == expected_out
True
    Similarly, with absolute paths:
    >>> elements = list_elements(os.path.abspath("."), extension=".py")
>>> expected_out = [
... os.path.join(os.path.abspath('.'), '__init__.py'), os.path.join(
... os.path.abspath('.'), 'generaldecorators.py'), os.path.join(
... os.path.abspath('.'), 'generaltools.py')]
>>> elements == expected_out
True
    print_progress(iteration, total, prefix='', suffix='', decimals=1, bar_length=100)[source]¶

    A nice way to show that your code is still running.

    This function prints a progress bar corresponding to the ratio between the number of iterations and the expected total number of iterations. The percentage is also shown in a numeric form. It can also display some custom information in two fields (prefix and suffix).

    Parameters:
    • iteration (int) – the number of iterations already past
    • total (int) – the expected total number of iterations
    • prefix (str, optional) – field to display custom information ( default is ‘’).
    • suffix (str, optional) – field to display custom information ( default is ‘’).
    • decimals (int, optional) – number of decimals to show.
    • bar_length (int, optional) –
    Returns:

    None
    Raises:

    None

    time_between_two_calls(raw=False)[source]¶

    A basic timer which returns the time spent since the last call.

    Generator of time durations. The first call initialise the generator with the current time and yields 0. All further calls yield the time spent since the precedent call.

    Parameters:raw (bool, optional) – Indicate if the time yielded is formatted (raw=False, by default) or not.
    Yields:tuple|float – Depending on raw yields a tuple of integers (h, min, s) or a float.
    Raises:AssertError – Raised when the types of the arguments are not respected.

    Examples

    >>> import time
>>> timer = time_between_two_calls()
>>> for _ in range(10):
...     t = timer.__next__()
...     time.sleep(0.1)
>>> result = timer.__next__()
>>> result == (0, 0, 0)
True
    time_points_to_time_length_in_h_min_sec(begin_time, end_time, to_int=True)[source]¶

    Takes to time points in second and returns the difference in h, min, s.

    Parameters:
    • begin_time (float|int) – First time point in seconds (e.g. given by time.time())
    • end_time (float|int) – Second time point in seconds (e.g. given by time.time())
    • to_int (bool) – Forces the output to be a tuple of integers
    Returns:

    Tuple containing the result in the form (h, min, s) where h, min and s are integers or floats depending on

    to_int
    Return type:

    tuple
    Raises:

    AssertError – Raised when the types of the arguments are not respected.
    time_since_first_call(raw=False)[source]¶

    A basic timer which returns the time spent since the first call.

    Generator of time durations. The first call initialise the generator with the current time and yields 0. All further calls yield the time spent since the first call.

    Parameters:raw (bool, optional) – Indicate if the time yielded is formatted (raw=False, by default) or not.
    Yields:tuple|float – Depending on raw yields a tuple of integers (h, min, s) or a float.
    Raises:AssertError – Raised when the types of the arguments are not respected.

    Examples

    >>> import time
>>> timer = time_since_first_call()
>>> for _ in range(10):
...     t = timer.__next__()
...     time.sleep(0.1)
>>> result = timer.__next__()
>>> result == (0, 0, 1)
True
